case_name: Insurance Company v. Chandmull Lal Chand

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 886 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 886 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated 13th/14th July, 1961

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 13th/14th July 1961 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 44 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated 13th/14th July, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 44 of 1959. B. Agarwala, B. M. Agarwala and L N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Divisional Bench reversed single Judge judgment and decreed respondents' claim for damages.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is taken from a judgment of the High Court of Calcutta, July 13 and 14, 1961, by which a Divisional Bench of the High Court, reversing the judgment of a learned single Judge of the same Court, decreed the respondents claim for damages.

facts.text: Appellant is General Assurance Society Ltd., a general insurance company.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances were these. The appellant is a general insurance companypany.

facts.text: Respondents submitted proposals on June 2, 1950 to insure houses in Dhulian Holding Nos. 274, 274/A-B-C-D and 273, 273/A-B-C-D for Rs. 51,000 and Rs. 65,000 against fire, cyclone, flood, change of river course, erosion, landslides, subsidence.

anchor.surface_text: On June 2, 1950 the respondents submitted proposals to the companypany with a view to insuring certain houses in Dhullian bearing Holding Nos. 274, 274/-A-B-C-and D and 273, 273/A-B- C and D, for Rs. 51,000 and Rs. 65,000 respectively against fire and including loss or damage by cyclone, flood and or change of companyrse of river or erosion of river, landslides and subsidence.

facts.text: Dhulian town situated on banks of Ganges, river changing course for several years, in 1949 part of town washed away.

anchor.surface_text: The town of Dhulian is situated on the banks of the Ganges and for several years the river had been changing its companyrse and in 1949 a part of the town was washed away. The insurance was obviously effected with this risk in sight.

facts.text: Insurance period from June 3, 1950 to June 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The period of insurance was to be from June 3, 1950 to June 2, 1951.

facts.text: Company accepted proposals by letters Ex. D on June 3, 1950, stating assured covered under cover numbers enclosed.

anchor.surface_text: The Company accepted the proposals by two letters  Ex.  D.  on June 3, 1950 and the letters stated that. in accordance with the proposal the assured was held companyered under companyer numberes enclosed with the letters.

facts.text: Cover notes dated June 5, 1950 for 30 days, subject to proposal terms and usual conditions of Society's policies.

anchor.surface_text: Two interim protection companyer numberes Nos.118848 and 18850 in respect of the two proposals were filed by the insurance companypany along with the written statement and they were said to be companyies of companyer numberes sent with the letters of acceptance, but they bore the date June 5, 1950.

facts.text: Dispute whether cover notes were enclosed with acceptance letters.

anchor.surface_text: There is some dispute as to whether they were at all enclosed with the reply showing acceptance of the proposals.

facts.text: Assured sent premium by cheque on June 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, the assured sent the premia by cheque.

facts.text: Assured wrote on July 1, 1950 (Ex. Ag) asking for policy or extension of cover notes.

anchor.surface_text: As numberpolicy was received by them, the assured wrote a letter on July 1  Ex. A g  asking for the policy or for extension of the companyer numberes.

facts.text: Company wrote on July 6, 1950 cancelling risk from July 6, 1950 based on inspection report.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950 the Company wrote to the assured two identi- cally worded letters  except for changes in amounts and numbers of the policies  which read Calcutta 6th July, 1950 TO M s Chandmull Lal Chand, P.O. Dhulian, Murshidabad.

facts.text: Assured replied on July 15, 1950 protesting cancellation as erosion had commenced.

anchor.surface_text: On July 15, 1950 the assured wrote to say that they held the Company bound because although there was numbererosion by the river when the proposals were submitted and accepted, the Company was trying to get out of the companytract when the river was eroding the banks.

facts.text: Company prepared and sent endorsement on July 17, 1950 cancelling insurance from July 6, 1950 with pro rata refund.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1950 the Company prepared an endorsement for the policies cancelling the risk and sent the endorsements to the assured. The endorsement read . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

facts.text: Houses washed away on 13th and 15th August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On 13th and 15th August the houses were washed away.

facts.text: Assured filed suit on Original Side of Calcutta High Court after demanding payment unsuccessfully.

anchor.surface_text: After unsuccessfully demanding payment under the policies, the assured filed the present suit on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Single Judge G.K. Mitter J. dismissed suit with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It was dismissed with companyts by G. K. Mitter J.

facts.text: Division Bench decreed claim for Rs. 1,10,000 with costs and 3% interest.

anchor.surface_text: but on appeal the claim was decreed to the extent of Rs. 1,10,000 with companyts, the decretal amount to carry interest at 3, per annum.

facts.text: On June 2, 1950 houses were 400/450 feet from river bank, no erosion, river calm till second week of June.

anchor.surface_text: Lalchand Jain  P.W.1  for the assured stated that on the 2nd of June the houses were 400/450 feet away from the bank of the river  Q. 73  and on that date there was numbererosion because the river was quite calm  Q. 132 .

facts.text: Erosion began end of June 1950, houses still 250 feet away on July 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Even on July 15, 1950 the distance between these houses and the river was 250 feet  Q. 179 .

facts.text: Erosion started 4-5 days after Rathajatra around June 20, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Surendranath Bhattacharjee W.2 , Overseer and Inspector, Dhulia Municipality stated that the erosion started four or five days after Rathajatra which took place on or about June 20, 1950.

facts.text: Rate of erosion 20-25 feet per day around August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: scouring must have been at the rate of 20-25 feet per day.

facts.text: P.K. Ghose (DW2) visited Dhulian on June 18, 1950 for inspection.

anchor.surface_text: with particular reference to the 18th June, 1950 when one P. K. Ghose  D.W. 2  visited Dhulian to make local inquiries on behalf of the Company

facts.text: Supreme Court held Condition 10 applies to all risks, cancellation valid as loss not commenced or inevitable on July 6, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The assurers were, therefore, within their rights under companydition 10 of the policy to cancel it.

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal must succeed. It is allowed.

Condition 10 of the Fire Policy read This insurance may be terminated at any time at the request of the Insured, in which case the Society will retain the customary short period rate for the time the policy has been in force. This insurance may also at any time be terminated at the option of the Society, on notice to that effect being given to the Insured, in which case the Society shall be liable to repay on demand a ratable proportion of the premium for the unexpired terms from the date of the cancelment.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to all risks including fire, cyclone, flood, erosion; mutual right to terminate at any time without reasons; valid if exercised before risk commences or becomes inevitable.

concepts.unlisted_description: Utmost good faith required in insurance contracts, particularly from the assured.

anchor.surface_text: the contract is likely to be construed contra proferentem that is against the company in case of ambiguity or doubt.

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule of construction against the drafter (insurer) in case of ambiguity in insurance contracts.

issues.text: Did condition 10 apply to the facts?

anchor.surface_text: Did condition 10 apply to the facts If it did, how is it to be construed and Was the cancellation of the policy valid in law? We consider the matter under these three broad heads.

issues.text: If it did, how is it to be construed?

anchor.surface_text: If it did, how is it to be construed and Was the cancellation of the policy valid in law? We consider the matter under these three broad heads. The application of condition 10 depends on how far the terms of the policy can be said to be incorporated in this contract of insurance between the parties.

issues.text: Was the cancellation of the policy valid in law?

anchor.surface_text: Was the cancellation of the policy valid in law? We consider the matter under these three broad heads. The application of condition 10 depends on how far the terms of the policy can be said to be incorporated in this contract of insurance between the parties. The facts relating to the formation of the contract are clear except on the one point relating to the cover notes,

issues.text: whether the cancellation was done after liability of the assurer under the policy had commenced or the loss had become inevitable

anchor.surface_text: The question thus is whether the cancellation was done after liability of the assurer under the policy had commenced or the loss had become inevitable. Here we must look at the evidence which was summarized earlier. We are concerned with two dates in particular and they are June 18, 1950 when Ghose visited Dhulian and July 6 when the policy was cancelled.

issues.text: how far the terms of the policy can be said to be incorporated in this contract of insurance between the parties

anchor.surface_text: The application of condition 10 depends on how far the terms of the policy can be said to be incorporated in this contract of insurance between the parties. The facts relating to the formation of the contract are clear except on the one point relating to the cover notes, and that, in our opinion, has been given undue prominence by the Divisional Bench.

arguments.claim: Company cancels the risk from 6th July, 1950 based on inspection report under implied condition 10.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950 the Company wrote to the assured two identi- cally worded letters  except for changes in amounts and numbers of the policies  which read Calcutta 6th July, 1950 TO M s Chandmull Lal Chand, P.O. Dhulian, Murshidabad. Dear Sir, In accordance with the inspection report lodged with this Co. we cancel the risk from 6th July, 1950 as per below.

arguments.claim: Condition 10 does not apply to any risk except fire and cannot protect after risk commenced.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge at the trial held that condition 10 of the policy applied to all the risks covered by the policy and not the risk from fire only.

arguments.claim: Condition 10 unreasonable and cannot be invoked after loss commenced or proximate.

arguments.claim: Cover notes integral to acceptance; incorporate usual policy terms by reference.

anchor.surface_text: The cover notes were an integral part of the acceptance of the proposals and the two had to be read together. A contract of insurance is a species of commercial transactions and there is a well-established commercial- practice to send cover notes

arguments.claim: Terms of standard policy govern even before issuance; presumption of usual terms applies.

anchor.surface_text: Where the contract to insure or issue a policy of fire insurance does not specify the terms and conditions of the policy, it is a general rule that the parties will be presumed to have contemplated a form of policy containing such conditions...

arguments.claim: Condition 10 gives mutual right to terminate at any time without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: the words in which the power of determination is expressed... are very wide... nothing is required except... a desire, on the part of the insurers, to get rid of future liability

arguments.claim: Cancellation valid unless risk already commenced or inevitable; here not on July 6.

anchor.surface_text: unless the risk has already commenced or become so imminent that it must inevitably take place, such a clause can be invoked.

arguments.claim: Follows Sun Fire Office and Hartford precedents on wide scope of condition 10.

anchor.surface_text: Such a condition is considered by the Privy Council in Sun Fire Office v. Hart... similar view... by this Court in the Hartford Fire Insurance Co. case

arguments.claim: Court cannot make new contract or imply reasonableness into express terms.

anchor.surface_text: the duty of the court is to interpret the words in which the contract is expressed by the parties because it is not for the court to make a new contract, however reasonable...

holdings.text: The terms and conditions of the usual policy accordingly governed the relations of the parties, and made condition 10 applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The terms and conditions of the usual policy accordingly governed the relations of the parties, and made condition 10 applicable. It was, however, contended that the policy itself never came into existence, because it was cancelled before it was issued and the endorsement of cancellation was engrossed and incorporated with the making of the policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cover notes integral to acceptance; incorporate standard policy terms by reference even if sent later; presumption of usual terms where not specified; no condition precedent for delivery.

holdings.text: Condition 10 gives mutual rights to the parties to cancel the policy at any time without requirement of reasons or judicial scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: the words in which the power of determination is expressed, taken by themselves, are very wide and comprehensive. According to their primary and natural meaning, they import that, in order to justify the exercise of the power, nothing is required except the existence of a desire, on the part of the insurers, to get rid of future liability

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation wide; follows Sun Fire Office (Privy Council) and Hartford Fire Insurance (this Court); condition usual and reasonable; court cannot imply limitations or make new contract.

holdings.text: It makes no essential difference whether the cover notes accompanied the letters of acceptance or were sent two days later.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relating to the formation of the contract are clear except on the one point relating to the cover notes, and that, in our opinion, has been given undue prominence by the Divisional Bench. It makes no essential difference whether the. cover notes accompanied the letters of acceptance or were sent two days later.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commercial practice; letters refer to cover notes; delay immaterial; assured gained no additional rights.

holdings.text: Cancellation under condition 10 valid unless risk has already commenced or become so imminent that it must inevitably take place.

anchor.surface_text: unless the risk has already commenced or become so imminent that it must inevitably take place, such a clause can be invoked. If property is insured against flood, it is not open to the insurance company to send runners on motor cycles ahead of the floods to cancel the policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle from precedents; applies to facts where no erosion/loss inevitable before cancellation.

holdings.text: The cancellation was done before liability commenced or loss inevitable; houses 400-500 ft away on July 6, no erosion yet.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it cannot be said that the loss had commenced or that it had become so certain as to be inevitable or that the cancellation was done in anticipation and with knowledge of inevitable loss. The cancellation was done at a time when no one could say with any degree of certainty that the houses were in such danger that the loss had commenced or became inevitable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence review: calm river till mid-June; erosion end-June; distance 250 ft even July 15; rate 20-25 ft/day; follows Sun Fire and Hartford.

holdings.text: The assurers were, therefore, within their rights under condition 10 of the policy to cancel it.

anchor.surface_text: The assurers were, therefore, within their rights under condition 10 of the policy to cancel it. As the policy was not ready they were justified in executing it and cancelling it. The right of the plaintiff to the policy and to enforce it was lost by the legal action of cancellations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis: incorporation + construction + fact application; policy cancelled validly before issuance.

anchor.surface_text: Relying, therefore, upon the dicta of the Judicial Committee in the Sun Fire Office Hart Ors. 1 , the learned Judge gave a wide meaning to condition 10 and held that the Company was within its rights in cancelling the policy as and when it did. The learned Judge pointed out that the condition was a usual provision in a policy of fire insurance and an assurer cancelling the policy under that 1 1889 14 A. C. 98. condition

precedents.case_name: Sun Fire Office v Hart Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: wide meaning to condition 10 allowing cancellation without reasons and motives not examinable by court

precedents.citation: The Sun Fire Office v. Hart and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In The Sun Fire Office v. Hart and Others 1 such a condition is not only mentioned but also discussed. An identical condition in a fire policy was also mentioned and discussed in a decision of this court reported in The Central Bank of India Ltd.v.Hartford Fire Insurance Co.Ltd. 2 . Therewas thus nothing unusual in the inclusion of such a condition in the policy and the reference to the usual conditions would, therefore, include a reference to condition  10 .

precedents.case_name: Sun Fire Office v Hart and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: condition allowing termination at will is usual and discussed

anchor.surface_text: Such a clause was considered by the Privy Council in Sun Fire Office v. Hart 2 . That was a case of a policy of insurance against fire. Certain fields of sugar cane were insured against fire. After insurance 3 fires happened and an anonymous letter was received that more fires would take place. The policy contained a condition that the insurers might terminate the policy by notice by reason of such change, or from any other cause whatever and the insurers cancelled the policy under that condition.

precedents.cited_proposition: insurer can terminate policy at will without needing to prove reasonable grounds or have them inquired into by court
precedents.cited_holding: insurers can act on their own judgment without assigning reasons satisfactory to court

anchor.surface_text: This case, therefore, falls within the rule of the Sun Fire Office 1 and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company 2 cases. The assurers were, therefore, within their rights under condition 10 of the policy to cancel it. As the policy was not ready they were justified in executing it and cancelling it. The right of the plaintiff to the policy and to enforce it was lost by the legal action of cancellations. 1 1889 14 A.C. 98.

In Eames v. Home Insurance Co. 1 the Supreme Court of the United States observed If no preliminary contract would be valid unless it specified minutely the terms to be contained in the policy to be issued, no such contract could ever be made or would ever be of any use. The very reason for sustaining such contracts is, that the parties may have the benefit of them during that incipient period when the papers are being perfected and transmitted.

precedents.cited_proposition: parties presumed to contemplate usual policy terms if not specified; sufficient if subject, period, amount, rate ascertained
precedents.cited_holding: preliminary contract valid without minutely specifying all terms

precedents.citation: General Accident Insurance Corporation v. Cronk 2

anchor.surface_text: In General Accident Insurance Corporation v. Cronk 2 , it was also ruled that a person making a proposal must be taken to have applied for the ordinary form of policy issued by the company. It is only when there is a condition precedent that the policy must be delivered that the assurer is not on the risk otherwise he is.

precedents.case_name: General Accident Insurance Corporation v Cronk
precedents.cited_proposition: proposal for insurance taken as for ordinary form of policy issued by company

precedents.citation: The Central Bank of India Ltd.v.Hartford Fire Insurance Co.Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: An identical condition in a fire policy was also mentioned and discussed in a decision of this court reported in The Central Bank of India Ltd.v.Hartford Fire Insurance Co.Ltd. 2 . Therewas thus nothing unusual in the inclusion of such a condition in the policy and the reference to the usual conditions would, therefore, include a reference to condition  10 .

precedents.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd v Hartford Fire Insurance Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: cancellation clause is common and reasonable, right to terminate at will not limited to reasonable cause

anchor.surface_text: But a similar view of an identical condition was taken by this Court in the Hartford Fire Insurance Co. case 1 . Sarkar J. there pointed out that a clause in this form was a common term in policies and must therefore be accepted as reasonable and that the right to terminate at will cannot, by reason of the circumstances, be read as a right to terminate for a reasonable cause.

precedents.cited_proposition: cancellation at will valid even after riots started but before loss
precedents.cited_holding: insurer protected by condition 10 despite proximate risk

anchor.surface_text: the rule of the Sun Fire Office 1 and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company 2 cases. The assurers were, therefore, within their rights under condition 10 of the policy to cancel it. As the policy was not ready they were justified in executing it and cancelling it. The right of the plaintiff to the policy and to enforce it was lost by the legal action of cancellations. A.I.R. 1956 S.C. 1288.

precedents.citation: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on the authority of Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd. 1 that the extreme width of the condition must be cut down by an implied limitation which was that the main object and intent of the contract should not be allowed to be defeated and that object and intent was the insuring of the property against floods and cancellation of the policy when floods had started would defeat the main object and intent of the contract.

precedents.case_name: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd v Rambler Cycle Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: cut down width of clause by implied limitation to prevent defeating main intent

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal must succeed. It is allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside; respondents' claim for damages dismissed

a11 states cover notes incorporate usual policy terms by reference, supporting c4

anchor.surface_text: ed cannot sustain the suit except by basing it upon the policy, because unless one reads the policy and the terms on which it was effective, mere read
